Award.AwardTitle: High Impact Technology Exchange (HI-TEC) 2018: Deepening Engagement and Strengthening Connections

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In 2009, several Centers funded through the Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program worked collaboratively to develop a conference that would broaden the impact across ATE supported industry areas. This annual High-Impact Technology (HI-TEC) conference has drawn participants mainly from the ATE program's community of centers and projects. The activities proposed for this project will open new opportunities nationwide for the ATE centers to broaden their impact and develop new networks of project and industry collaborators in their areas of technology focus. This broadening can increase the impact of ATE projects across the nation and strengthen the American economy in high-demand fields that drive our most competitive industries. The proposed project will also strengthen HI-TEC's ability to help address issues faced in technological education everywhere. Examples of such cross-cutting issues include recruitment of diverse and underserved student populations, integration of research into the classroom, faculty development techniques, and best practices in education/industry partnerships.

The theme of the 2018 conference is "Partnering with Industry for the New American Workforce." The proposed activities would build upon HI-TEC's record of success to accomplish three goals: 1) Expand engagement in the conference by industry, ATE projects, and faculty engaged in advanced technological education who may not be currently supported by the ATE program; 2) Strengthen actionable connections between ATE projects and centers and others associated with the ATE community; and 3) Deepen sharing and broaden implementation of evidence-based models and best practices used by ATE projects and centers. These activities will be conducted within the framework of HI-TEC's existing structure, and will strengthen HI-TEC's impact nationally and, in turn, strengthen the impact of ATE centers and projects. This project will develop two new opportunities for participant engagement at the conference: the Technological Education Forum (TEF) and the Industry Partnerships Forum (IPF). Educators and industry personnel will learn from each other and collaborate to address issues facing advanced technological education. The conference's design, which stresses pedagogy, technology, program building, and workforce development, provides a unique professional development opportunity that enables educators to acquire new knowledge and skills. The evaluation activities will focus on both short-term outcomes and medium-term performance-based outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The High Impact Technology Education Conference (HI-TEC) is produced by a consortium of centers and projects funded through the National Science Foundation's Advanced Technological Education (NSF ATE) program. The theme is Preparing America's Skilled Technical Workforce.

Since its inception in 2009, HI-TEC has provided a national forum for addressing critical issues in advanced technological education. HI-TEC participants learn about applications of cutting-edge technology and engage in interactive workshops and sessions focusing on a broad range of related topics such as recruitment of diverse and underserved student populations, integration of research into the classroom, faculty development techniques, and best practices in education-industry partnerships. HI-TEC is a unique event that grew out of the NSF ATE community, which continues to shepherd the event in collaboration with industry and education partners. HI-TEC typically attracts 500-600 educators, industry representatives, workforce development personnel, and technicians/students who share an interest in improving technician education at community colleges. This project supports the continued development of the conference in 2018 and 2019.

HI-TEC builds professional capacity among educators across the country in the form of teaching and training of faculty and developing partnerships with industry. The impacts can include gaining new skillsets, new understandings of industry needs, new engagement with questions of diversity and inclusion, as well as other contributions to developing human resources. Ultimately the contribution to society is the development of the future technician workforce.

This project asked to what extent were conference participants inspired to take action based on what they learned at the conference? What actions did they actually take? Surveys for specific groups of attendees showed about half actually took actions as a result of attending, these included intending to use new approaches and new ideas. The second most often cited action taken was enhancing connections with industry.

In the words of one attendee:  the most beneficial to me were the subjects that did not focus on a specific field but focused on how I can adapt what they did to what we do.

HI-TEC promotes connections and the attendees found the networking opportunities one of the most valuable experiences for them.  In one attendee's words: Talking with faculty members from across the country and learning about some of their best practices and engaging student strategies is something that I will definitely share with my faculty during the fall semester.

The conference, by promoting the partnerships with industry for the highly skilled technical American workforce, has developed and disseminated ideas and methods that significantly broaden under-represented participation in that workforce. The enhanced skills and diversity of the workforce are a significant societal benefit.
